title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: But Doctor Blair came forward to me andshook me warmly by the hand, and was full of gossip about Clydesdale,from which apparently he had been absent these twenty years.

title: Salute to Adventurers
author: Buchan, John
snippet: They had clapped himinto prison; but the man, being three parts mad had been let go, andever since had been making strife in the westland parts of Clydesdale.

title: Hunted and Harried
author: Ballantyne, R. M. (Robert Michael)
snippet: The Reverend John Blackadder, the "auld" minister ofTroqueer--a noted hero of the Covenant, who afterwards died a prisoneron the Bass Rock--travelled with his party all the way from Edinburgh,and a company of eighty horse proceeded to the meeting from Clydesdale.

title: Hunted and Harried
author: Ballantyne, R. M. (Robert Michael)
snippet: The Reverend John Blackadder, the "auld" minister ofTroqueer--a noted hero of the Covenant, who afterwards died a prisoneron the Bass Rock--travelled with his party all the way from Edinburgh,and a company of eighty horse proceeded to the meeting from Clydesdale.

title: Noctes Ambrosianæ.
author: Wilson, John
snippet: I saw severals — but whether they were coming or going — in motion or at rest, it is not for me to say — but they, and the hills, and woods, and clouds, seemed a' to be floatin awa thegither in the direction o' the mountains at the head o' Clydesdale.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In Berwickshire, the Lothians, Clydesdale, Fifeshire, the Carses of Stirling, Falkirk, and more particularly  in the Carse of Gowrie, Strathearn, Strathmore, and Moray, there are tracts of land not inferior to any in the empire.

title: Bonnie Scotland.
author: [Lippincott, Sara Jane Clarke]
snippet: He afterwards retired to the forest recesses of Clydesdale, where he made himself more and more formidable to the English, — more and more beloved by the poor Scots.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: The spur was duly delivered — the hint was accepted, and the brawl at the gate seemed explained ; for within an hour, Hamilton and his followers were far on the road to Clydesdale and the castle of Cadzow.

title: Benedict's wanderings, in Ireland, Scotland, Italy and Sicily ...
author: Dawson, Edward W[alter] [from old catalog]
snippet: Of the bank buildings  brought to our notice, I remember the National, in the Italian style ; the City of Glasgow, after the model of the Jupiter Stator at Rome ; the office of the Western Banking Company, a palatial structure ; the Clydesdale, a plain edifice ; and the Royal, after the model of the Temple of Minerva at Athens.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: And she would have been thefarther disinclined to request any favour of LordEvandale bpcause the voice of the gossips inClydesdale had, for reasons hereafter to be madeknown, assigned him to her as a suitor, and becauseshe could not disguise from herself that very littleencouragement was necessary to realize conjectureswhich had hitherto no foundation.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Ill luck be in the graning corse o'thee ! Tlieprettiest lad in Clydesdale this day maun be a sufferer, and a' for you and your daft whiggery!"" Gae wa'," replied Mause; " I trow ye are yetiu the bonds of sin, and in the gall of iniquity, togrudge your bonniest and best in the cause of Himthat gave ye a' ye hae—I promise I hae dune asmuckle for Mr Harry as I wad do for my ain ; foils Cuddie was found worthy to bear testimony inthe Grassmarket "

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " And what o' a' this, ye fule wife ? Or what hadNebuchadnezzar to do wi' the wappen-schaw ol theUpper Ward of Clydesdale ?"" Only just thus far, my leddy," continued Manse,firmly, " that prelacy is like the golden image in theplain of Dura, and that as Shadrach, Meshach, andAbednego, were borne out in refusing to bow downand worship, so neither shall Cuddy Headrigg, yourleddyship's pcor pleughman, at least wi' his auldmither's consent, make murgeons or jenny-flections,as they ca' them, in the house of the prelates andcurates, nor gird him wi' armour to fight in theircause, either at the sound of kettle drums, organs,bagpipes, or ony other kind of music whatever."

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The sheriff of the county of Lanark was holdingthe wappen-schaw ofa wild district, called the Upper Ward of Clydesdale, on a haugh or level plain,near to a royal borough, the name of which is noway essential to my story, upon the morning ofthe 5th of May, 1679, when our narrative commences.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: First, the natives of Clydesdale, and the adjacent districts of Scotland, southof the Forth ; next, the natives of Scotland on thenorth of the Forth ; then the natives of the westHighlands and of Ireland ; and last, of the easterndistricts of Scotland, of England, America, and theColonies.
